body: Next time you make a PR, let me review it before you merge.
Fixed in #9.
What are the criteria for an unsupported browser?
Browsers that don't support certain features of html5. Research must be done on which browsers and what versions of those browsers will be able to run all of our website and which will not.

Also I believe it's a feature since we're adding in the ability to give an alert to the user that their browser is not supported. It's not an enhancement because it's not adding to anything specifically and it's not documentation because we're not documenting anything
I added the documentation label because we should record browsers that are known to be unsupported. But your justification is reasonable, I think we can make that its own issue.
You could've given this pull request a better name.
Fixed in PR #14.
Would it be reasonable and useful to have this feature list specifically which features are unsupported by the browser?

Why would there be unsupported browsers? Are you using HTML5 or something
new?
On Oct 19, 2015 7:32 PM, "ammongit" notifications@github.com wrote:

> Would it be reasonable and useful to have this feature list specifically
> which features are unsupported by the browser?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/BradleyCai/ucr-class-map/issues/16#issuecomment-149408328
> .
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7998948/10596371/4bc10552-7698-11e5-9cff-c971c9d7486d.png)

Well shoot why don't we just use html4? Or is there a specific feature from
5 you want?
On Oct 19, 2015 7:33 PM, "Bradley Cai" notifications@github.com wrote:

> [image: image]
> https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7998948/10596371/4bc10552-7698-11e5-9cff-c971c9d7486d.png
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/BradleyCai/ucr-class-map/issues/16#issuecomment-149408793
> .
![screenshot from 2015-10-19 19 35 25](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8848022/10596401/97ff8934-7698-11e5-91cc-b3f8da1f53e6.png)

It would be somewhat unreasonable to find every feature that is unsupported by every browser. What I was thinking was to just give a warning if the browser isn't an up to date version of chrome/firefox/safari/etc.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7998948/10596406/a9581624-7698-11e5-83c1-515059a62f1f.png)
@BradleyCai Sounds fair enough. Can you find out what the minimum version for the major browsers is?
@FuzzyAvacado We are using Canvases to represent the schedule as an image. The client side image downloading also has some HTML5 magic sprinkled in
![screenshot from 2015-10-19 19 37 26](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8848022/10596420/da70aa14-7698-11e5-98c3-a6300defcfda.png)
@BradleyCai We should make the website as backwards-compatible as possible. Does the website work (sans the image downloading) without HTML5?
When this issue is picked up we'll figure out the minimum version of all major browsers

If someone is using a browser that doesn't support html5, they are either
using an embedded browser in their IDE or their grandmothers computer on
loan to them.
On Oct 19, 2015 7:38 PM, "Bradley Cai" notifications@github.com wrote:

> When this issue is picked up we'll figure out the minimum version of all
> major browsers
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/BradleyCai/ucr-class-map/issues/16#issuecomment-149410598
> .
@ammongit This will be research for a later time; the impression I had is that drawing on images without HTML5 is much more difficult.
@FuzzyAvacado Or possibly a mobile device, though @BradleyCai has been doing testing for mobile browsers.
If the user has a browser that doesn't support HTML5 they should still have access to the main and core features of the website.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7998948/10596509/d0d4b4b8-7699-11e5-8de4-2378bab87bef.png)
Buildings should be stored in a json. Each building abbreviation will have a corresponding building location link at http://campusmap.ucr.edu/imap/index.html

Instead of creating a JSON, we can just enter the building directly.
e.g.: `http://campusmap.ucr.edu/imap/index.html?loc=%s` where `%s` is replaced with the building name, say `BRNHL`.
I think that if both building and room are `TBA` then it should only display once. Otherwise, I think this is a good change. `BCOE TBA` is much more informative than just a blank line.
@ammongit I'll add that right now
Looks good.
